results.title: The St Arnaud boys
results.creator_credit: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norm started his life in the Army with six other local boys from his local area. He really enjoyed the mateship and sense of community he shared with them, and reminisces on the good times they had over the years. The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Norm started his life in the Army with six other local boys from his local area. He really enjoyed the mateship and sense of community he shared with them, and reminisces on the good times they had over the years. The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.

The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.

results.title: On the road again
results.creator_credit: Bill Medlyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: In 1942, Bill joined the army, taking his brothers place who returned home to work on the farm. Bill worked in many capacities as a driver and instructor. Having a severe driving accident on a mission, Bill landed in hospital for three months with a fractured spine. Making a good recovery, he was able to return to service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Medlyn, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: In 1942, Bill joined the army, taking his brothers place who returned home to work on the farm. Bill worked in many capacities as a driver and instructor. Having a severe driving accident on a mission, Bill landed in hospital for three months with a fractured spine. Making a good recovery, he was able to return to service.

results.title: A Life on the farm
results.creator_credit: Oz Sanderson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Oz Sanderson grew up on his farm with his two brothers during the Great Depression. His dad signed a consent form for him to join the army. While Oz was determined to serve as a pilot, the farm was always in his heart and he was more than happy to return to it after the war ended.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oz Sanderson, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Land and sea
results.creator_credit: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keith Payne had a terrible acne problem when he was a youngster but it only got worse when he was deployed into the tropics. Unfortunately for Payne, his attempts to sign up to volunteer in Japan were shot down when the doctors looked at his acne and sent him home.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Keith Payne, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: I've been everywhere
results.creator_credit: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Robert Flisher was excited to leave Australia and see the world as it was his childhood dream to join the Navy. Flisher opens up about his experiences with the Navy and talks about some of the exciting places he visited during his service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rob Flisher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Robert Flisher was excited to leave Australia and see the world as it was his childhood dream to join the Navy. Flisher opens up about his experiences with the Navy and talks about some of the exciting places he visited during his service.

results.title: A Cook's tour
results.creator_credit: Bryan Chipperfield, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Bryan Chipperfield saw no action during his service in the air force. Posted to Calgary in Canada, Chipperfield was able to enjoy skiing, boating and playing sports. Keeping up to date with the war through reading the paper, he knew he may be asked to ‘play his part’ at any time.

Read by fellow veteran Bill Medlyn for Bryan Chipperfield

results.title: A Chance to travel
results.creator_credit: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: When George Snowden joined the Australian army, he was given the opportunity to tour Australia. Despite being given the chance to travel across the country, Snowden ended up suffering from a knee injury and was happy to return home after seeing most of the country.
results.creator_credit_for_label: George Snowden, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: In our words: stories from Victorian veterans [September 2010]
results.brief_description: ACMI’s Digital Storytelling unit interviewed ten Victorian war veterans for their perspectives on life in the army, being involved in war in a different country and adjusting to life back in Australia. The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

The personal experiences of these soldiers provide a moving memoir and a compelling historical account of Australia in wartime.

results.title: An Interview with Laurie Price
results.creator_credit: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Laurie Price, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.description: Laurie Price is one of the remaining third of those Australians who served in Korea. He provides sharp detail of the work he performed there on the airfields, the distractions and tensions, even between allies. While the war is long over, it continues to affect Price even today.

results.title: An Interview with John Balloch
results.brief_description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.
results.description: John Balloch was at school when war was declared. Even so, he couldn’t wait to sign up. He wanted to be a fighter pilot, flying alone. He tells of his training and time serving in the RAAF during World War II and pays tribute to those lost, both to the enemy and accidents.
